title: Opinion: Mike Shanahan's blueprint paving way for Sean McVay, Kyle Shanahan, Matt LaFleur
text:

The three disciples have gone their separate ways, and the teacher has retired.

But when Mike Shanahan watches Kyle Shanahan, Sean McVay and Matt LaFleur establish themselves in the NFL, he smiles.

“It actually is fun,” the two-time Super Bowl-winning head coach told USA TODAY Sports in a recent telephone interview. “You can call the formations, call the plays, you can call the blocking schemes. They all have a different game plan for each opponent. Each guy has different things to add to the offense, building on what they’ve learned. So that’s also fun to watch.”

When he hired the trio as members of his staff in Washington in 2010, Shanahan raised some eyebrows. Although his son had started to develop a reputation as a bright offensive mind during his time in Houston, LaFleur (hired to serve as Washington’s quarterbacks coach) and McVay (initially an assistant tight ends coach and then elevated to tight ends coach) were unknowns.

Mike Shanahan, in 2013 when he was head coach of the Redskins. His son, in the background, was offensive coordinator. (Photo: Geoff Burke, USA TODAY Sports)

But Shanahan saw great potential in each because of their work ethic, high football IQ and leadership skills.

“You could tell – as I told you guys in Washington – it wouldn’t be long before Sean was going to be a coordinator and then a head coach,” Shanahan recalled. “It wasn’t going to be long before Kyle was going to be a head coach, and once Matt got his opportunity to be quarterbacks coach, and then a coordinator, I knew it wouldn’t be long before he would get his opportunity to be a head man as well.”

Now, here they are: three of the brightest minds in football, all charged with leading franchises back to former glory.

McVay and the L.A. Rams are trying to get back to the Super Bowl after losing to New England last winter. Kyle Shanahan, also in his third season, has the San Francisco 49ers off to a 5-0 start (remaining perfect after a 20-7 victory over McVay’s Rams last Sunday). LaFleur, in his first season as a head coach, has Green Bay at 5-1.

Said Mike Shanahan, “You go to different organizations and everyone has different strengths and weaknesses and you’ve got to find a way to build it and give yourself a chance to win consistently. I think all three have a really good background in that: understanding how to turn an organization around, having been around some good situations, some tough situations. ... They’re all in football organizations that will give them a chance to do the little things the right way.”

Each young coach’s journey has unfolded differently: McVay with a rapid turnaround; Kyle Shanahan with a gradual build; LaFleur inheriting a team in win-now mode. However, all three are following the same blueprint to success, Mike Shanahan points out.

Each approaches his job with a strong emphasis on attention to detail, accountability, strong communication so everyone from top to bottom is on the same page and maintaining a standard of excellence.

All three are offensive coaches, as was their mentor, but they understand that the other side of the ball can’t be addressed haphazardly.

“The first thing you do is, you have to have a great defense to win a Super Bowl, and we all know that,” the two-time Super Bowl-winning coach insisted.

McVay’s first move was to hire Wade Phillips, regarded as one of the game’s great defensive minds for the better part of the last three decades. Kyle Shanahan tabbed former Houston coworker Robert Saleh as his defensive coordinator and devoted high draft picks to fortifying that unit. LaFleur retained Mike Pettine as his defensive coordinator, and the Packers worked aggressively this offseason to upgrade that unit.

The third key involves constructing offenses that feature strong rushing attacks.

It’s a passing league, yes. But all three coaches strive for balance because a feeble run game diminishes the passing attack in Mike Shanahan’s book.

“To be able to move the ball consistently, you have to believe in the running game, and everybody has to believe in it,” he explained. “And the one thing that all three of them do is the play-action game and the running game look exactly the same. People will not be able to tell when they’re running the ball or throwing play-action off of it, and that gives them the opportunity to get big plays throughout the game. All three guys have that foundation. When you look at their systems, there’s a lot of different personnel groupings, a lot of different ways to do things, but the running game and the play-action game go hand-in-hand. You can do tight splits and wide splits and both systems will come up with big plays.”

It’s no coincidence that Goff and the Rams have faltered, losing three in a row while struggling in the rushing department. They managed just 28 yards on the ground against Tampa Bay, 82 the following week against Seattle and then had to go without Todd Gurley against San Francisco.

For much of this season and last postseason, Gurley has not been the same potent back he usually is. An arthritic knee has diminished his explosiveness, causing the Rams' coaches to use him more sparingly, hoping to preserve him for the long haul. He's averaging 4.2 yards a carry (down from 4.9 last season) and only 4.9 yards a reception (down from 9.8 last year). And last Sunday, a quad injury kept him from playing.

As a result, the Rams’ offense has lacked the same balance, unpredictability and potency. However, Shanahan believes McVay will figure out how to get his team back on track.

“Sean runs a system that’s perfect for the personnel he has,” Shanahan said. “Even if he doesn’t have that personnel, he’s going to adjust that system to fit the personnel. That’s how Sean is.”

And for the long-term, Shanahan predicts continued success for all three former assistants. He saw these principles produce multiple Super Bowls during his days as an assistant in San Francisco and implemented them as a head coach in Denver. And because he knows the men, and the blueprint they’re following, Shanahan is betting on similar results for Kyle Shanahan, McVay and LaFleur.

“I will not be surprised,” he said. “People enjoy watching them for years to come.”

description: As three of his former assistants establish themselves in the NFL head coaching ranks, Mike Shanahan breaks down their keys to success.
